title: Christopher Hunter visits the Wall
The Act of Union unites England and Scotland into Great Britain

note: Wall is produced by J. Goeree. 1708–9 Robert Smith visits the Wall.
title: The first graphic reconstruction of the Picts
A rebellion by Jacobite forces causes concern in the frontier region
As a result of the rebellion, John Warburton surveys the Wall, producing an authoritative map.*
Sir John Clerk and Alexander Gordon visit the Wall
William Stukeley and Roger Gale visit the Wall
Alexander Gordon’s account of the Wall is published.*
John Horsley’s influential account of the Wall is published in his monograph on Roman Britain. The Vallum is ascribed to Hadrian and the stone curtain Wall to Severus.*

note: which is described and illustrated in print by George Smith. +
title: Susana Maria Appleby excavates a bath-house at Castlesteads
A second Jacobite rebellion penetrates the line of the Wall as the rebels march south to Derby
George Smith calls on the spirit of the Roman Wall in order to preventing further problems in the frontier regions
Dugal Campbell and Hugh Debbieg produce a detailed survey of the remains of the Wall as part of the planning for the new road between Newcastle and Carlisle.*
An Act of Parliament is passed to require the construction of this new military road
John Warburton publishes the first book entirely dedicated to the Wall. He writes of the ‘re-edification’ of the Roman Wall through the building of the new military road.*
William Stukeley attempts to get the line of the new road moved to avoid the serious damage that is currently occurring to the Wall
William Stukeley’s account of the Wall is published posthumously.*
William Hutton may have been the first person to walk the entire length of the Wall and his experiences are published in a small but influential book.*
The foundation of the Society of Antiquaries of Newcastle upon Tyne focuses renewed attention on the Wall
Walter Scott narrates the ‘celebrated’ Roman Wall in his novel Guy Mannering
John Hodgson writes an account of the excavation of the Mithraeum at Housesteads

John Hodgson publishes an influential account of the Wall, includes a detailed argument for the building of the curtain Wall by Hadrian.* 1843–1890 John Clayton excavates much of the site at Chesters, next to his country house
Clayton starts to excavate the Roman site at Housesteads

note: + 1848–1873 Clayton has the curtain Wall on Whin Sill rebuilt, creating the ‘Clayton Wall’.
title: Clayton’s excavation at Cawfields milecastle locate a gateway through the curtain Wall, indicating that the Wall may have been more permeable than was previously thought
John Collingwood Bruce leads the First Pilgrimage to the Wall and presents a lecture on imperial comparison at Housesteads
1851 Bruce publishes The Roman Wall.*
The growth of interest in the Roman frontiers in Germany stimulates new interest in the Roman Wall
The Duke of Northumberland hopes to promote a significant project on the Roman Wall, but this does not succeed
William Bell Scott paints the Building of the Roman
Bruce publishes The Wallet-Book, providing a handy volume for visitors to take with them along the Wall.*

container-title: + 1880–1883 The Glasgow Archaeological Society conducts a programme of work on Roman sites along the Antonine Wall in Scotland
title: The foundation of the Cumberland and Westmorland Society focused attention on the west end of the Wall 1876–1877 Discovery and excavation of Coventina’s Well. + 1870–1880 Excavations undertaken at the Roman site at South Shields resulted in the creation of an archaeological Park
The German ancient historian Theodor Mommsen describes England’s Roman Wall as the ‘best known’ Roman military work
The German Limes-Commission is founded and members visit the Roman Walls of Britain during the following year
A significant programme of work commences on the Wall, exploring its constituent elements, dating, and sequence
1895 Discovery of the Turf Wall close to Birdoswald.*
Reginald Bosanquet conducts extensive excavations at Housesteads in an effort to uncover the entire plan of the fort.*

Francis Haverfield reviews the first five years of the major excavation programme. He is still uncertain about the dating of the Wall, arguing in a subsequent article that the Vallum was built by Hadrian and the curtain Wall by Severus.*
Robert Forster publishes an imaginative book about the Wall, entitled The Amateur Antiquary.*
Rudyard Kipling writes about the Wall in Puck of Pook’s Hill, a novel which influences generations of school children.* 1906–1914 Significant excavations are undertaken at the Roman site at Corbridge
Kipling uses the Wall as a metaphor for Englishness in a lecture to the Royal Society of St George

Collingwood writes an article summarizing the state of play with the ongoing research into the Wall and a second article on the function of the Wall. He argues that most elements of the Wall, including the curtain Wall are Hadrianic in date.*
Collingwood publishes a popular guide to the Wall.*
Eric Birley acquires the farm at Vindolanda
A quarrying threat to the central sections of the Wall leads to a strengthening of the Ancient Monuments legislation
Significant sections of the Wall are acquired by the National Trust and by the Ministry of Public Buildings and Works, guaranteeing its protection and public access to its remains
Collingwood argues for the existence of a system of Roman frontier defenses along the Cumbrian coast at the west of the Wall

note: an ironic reflection on the Wall’s imperial purpose.*
title: Auden writes ‘Roman Wall Blues’
The first international Congress of Roman Frontier Studies is organized by Eric Birley at Newcastle upon Tyne.*
Ian Richmond argues that the principle questions about the Wall have been answered
A major dispute arises about the best way to conserve the curtain Wall
The construction of the Berlin Wall casts a negative light on Hadrian’s Wall
The Vindolanda Trust is founded and excavation and reconstruction work commences
Hunter Davies published a popular account that seeks to animate the Wall.*
Excavation at Wallsend uncover the plan of the fort, which had been covered in housing
Significant excavation work is conducted on the curtain Wall on Whin Sill by Jim Crow, indicating that the Hadrianic Wall was rebuilt, probably under Severus
The remains of Hadrian’s Wall are inscribed as a World Heritage Site
Significant excavations at Birdoswald by Tony Wilmott produced important information for the post-Roman history of the site
The reconstructed Roman gateway at South Shields is opened
The dismantling of the Berlin Wall
The discovery of ‘obstacles’ on the berm between the curtain Wall and northern ditch during excavations at Buddle Street, Wallsend reignites the debate about the function of the Wall
The Roman fort, museum, and interpretation centre at Wallsend is opened to the public
The creation of the ‘Hadrian’s Wall Country Brand’ aims to help local businesses to recover from an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease
The opening of the Hadrian’s Wall National Trail provides coordinated access to the remains of the Wall
The discovery of Ilam Pan, a Roman patera, which includes text related to Hadrian’s Wall
The Roman Limes in Germany are inscribed as part of the Frontiers of the Roman World Heritage Site
Hadrian’s Wall Heritage Ltd is formed to supervise and manage the Wall
The Hadrian’s Wall National Cycle Route is opened
A collection of art works inspired by the Wall, ‘Writing on the Wall’
The fourteenth Handbook to the Roman Wall
The Arts and Humanities Research Council funds the Tales of the Frontier project, the initiative from which this book arose.*
The Antonine Wall is inscribed as part of the Frontiers of the Roman Empire World Heritage Site
The latest Management Plan for Hadrian’s Wall is published.*
The Archaeological Research Framework for Hadrian’s Wall is published.*
The Thirteenth Pilgrimage explores the remains of Hadrian’s Wall
The twenty-first Congress of Roman Frontier Studies is held at Newcastle upon Tyne
The English Heritage map of Hadrian’s Wall is published.*
Ambitious proposals are developed to undertake major excavation and create a visitor experience at Maryport
